Situation1: The ambulance is transporting a critically ill patient through a severe thunderstorm with slick roads and low visibility.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A neighboring family has been affected by a house fire and requires immediate assistance with food and clothing.
Story: The wipers thrashed against the windshield as I gripped the steering wheel, my knuckles white. The ambulance’s siren wailed, echoing my own racing heart. The patient in the back was barely clinging to life, and every second counted, but the rain hammered down so hard I could barely see the road. I knew I had to drive safely—one wrong move and we could all end up in a ditch. Yet, my phone buzzed with a message from Sister Agnes: the family next door had lost everything in a fire. They needed help—food, blankets, comfort. As a nun, I was expected to be there, to serve, to offer solace. But right now, my duty as an ambulance driver demanded my full attention. I felt torn, guilt gnawing at me. Was I failing my calling as a nun by not rushing to the family’s aid? Or would I betray my patient’s trust if I let my mind wander from the treacherous road? The storm outside was nothing compared to the turmoil inside me as I wrestled with what to do next.
